{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1973 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = 11 | APRank = 7 | Record = 9-2-1 | ConfRecord = 4-2-1 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Tom Osborne]] | HCYear = 1st | OffCoach = Tom Osborne | OCYear = 5th | DefCoach = [[Monte Kiffin]] | DCYear = 1st | OScheme = [[I formation]] | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = Cotton Bowl Classic Champions | BowlTourney = [[Cotton Bowl Classic]] vs. #8 {{cfb link|year=1973|school=The University of Texas|team=Texas Longhorns|title=Texas}} | BowlTourneyResult = W 19-3 | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1973 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1973 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1973 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Tom Osborne]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. ==Schedule== {{Cite web |url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1973 |title =Football - 1973 Schedule/Results |accessdate=2009-06-16 |publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln '''Zanetich, Nick''' #62 ''(So.)'' G |- | colspan="5" valign="bottom" align="right" |       |} ==Coaching staff== {| class="wikitable" |- |align="left"|'''Name'''||align="left"|'''Title'''||align="center"|'''First year
in this position''' ||align="center"|'''Years at
Nebraska''' ||align="left"|'''Alma Mater''' |- |'''[[Tom Osborne]]'''|||[[Head Coach]]
[[Offensive Coordinator]]||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1964-97||[[Hastings College|Hastings]] |- |'''[[Monte Kiffin]]'''|||[[Defensive Coordinator]]||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1967-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Cletus Fischer'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"| ||align="center"|1960-85||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Jim Ross'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1962-76|| |- |'''John Melton'''|||Tight Ends, Wingbacks||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1962-88||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''Mike Corgan'''|||Running Backs||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-82||[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |- |'''[[Warren Powers]]'''|||Defensive Backs||align="center"| ||align="center"|1969-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Boyd Epley'''|||Head Strength Coach||align="center"|1969||align="center"|1969-2003||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Bill Myles'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"|1972||align="center"|1972-76|| |- |'''[[Jerry Moore]]'''|||Wide Receivers||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1973-78||[[Baylor University|Baylor]] |- |'''George Darlington'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1973-2002||[[Rutgers University|Rutgers]] |- |'''Rick Duval'''|||Linebackers
Recruiting Coordinator||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1973-74||[[Worcester State College|Worcester]] |} ==Game notes== ===UCLA=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#10 UCLA at #4 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #10 {{cfb link|year=1973|school=University of California, Los Angeles|team=UCLA Bruins|title=UCLA}} | Host = '''#4 Nebraska''' | V1 = 6| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 6| H3 = 6| H4 = 14 | Date = 1973-09-08 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 74,966 }} {{AFB game box end}} The Tom Osborne era at Nebraska began in style, as the Cornhuskers exacted revenge for last year's loss to UCLA by beating the #10 Bruins in Lincoln 40-13. Nebraska jumped out to a 14-0 lead in less than 10 minutes, and though UCLA scored to come within 8, that was as close as they'd get for the rest of the game as the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] shut out the Bruins entirely in the 2nd half. {{-}} ===NC State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#14 NC State at #2 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #14 {{cfb link|year=1973|school=North Carolina State University|team=NC State Wolfpack|title=NC State}} | Host = '''#2 Nebraska''' | V1 = 7| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 7| H3 = 3| H4 = 21 | Date = 1973-09-22 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 75,925 }} {{AFB game box end}} It was touch and go for Nebraska as the Cornhuskers fought to stay even with NC State until blowing the game wide open in the 4th quarter with three straight unanswered touchdowns. {{-}} ===Wisconsin=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Wisconsin at #2 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1973 Wisconsin Badgers football team|Wisconsin]] | Host = '''#2 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 7| V3 = 0| V4 = 9 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 13 | Date = 1973-09-29 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,279 }} {{AFB game box end}} Wisconsin fought Nebraska to a 7-7 tie entering the 4th quarter before pulling ahead by 3 on a field goal with 8 minutes to go. The Cornhuskers replied with a touchdown, which was promptly answered by a 96-yard Badger kickoff return to put Nebraska behind again. Nebraska again responded, marching 83 yards in just seven plays to score again for the win. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#2 Nebraska at Minnesota''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#2 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1973 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | V1 = 7| V2 = 14| V3 = 13| V4 = 14 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1973-10-06 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium (University of Minnesota)|Memorial Stadium]], [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 58,091 }} {{AFB game box end}} Minnesota QB [[Tony Dungy]] managed to get a 1st quarter touchdown, and that would be the last time the Golden Gophers saw the scoreboard, as the first Minnesota sellout since 1960 (with help from the numerous traveling Cornhusker fans) watched Nebraska dismantle the Gophers 48-7. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#2 Nebraska at Missouri''' [box score] | Visitor = #2 Nebraska | Host = '''{{cfb link|year=1973|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}}''' | V1 = 6| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 6 | H1 = 0| H2 = 6| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1973-10-13 | Location = [[Faurot Field]], [[Columbia, Missouri]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 68,720 }} {{AFB game box end}} Missouri handed coach [[Tom Osborne]] his first career defeat as Nebraska's 2 point conversion for the win with 1:00 remaining was intercepted, marking the first time Coach Osborne decided to forgo the tie and take a shot at the win, an approach later repeated to much attention in the [[1984 Orange Bowl]]. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#18 Kansas at #11 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #18 {{cfb link|year=1973|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | Host = '''#11 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 3| V3 = 6| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 3 | Date = 1973-10-20 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,498 }} {{AFB game box end}} Kansas avoided the 1st half shutout on a recovered Nebraska fumble converted into a field goal. The Jayhawks then came out from halftime and continued to hold off Nebraska while putting in their own touchdown late in the 3rd to pull ahead, though the PAT was blocked. Less than five minutes later, Nebraska responded with a field goal to pull ahead by 1 point, where a tie would have existed had the previous Kansas PAT attempt been good. From there on out, the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] held on for the rest of the quarter to preserve the razor thin winning margin. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#10 Nebraska at Oklahoma State''' [box score] | Visitor = #10 Nebraska | Host = {{cfb link|year=1973|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | V1 = 10| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 10| H2 = 7| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1973-10-27 | Location = [[Boone Pickens Stadium|Lewis Field]], [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 50,500 }} {{AFB game box end}} With seven minutes remaining in a fierce contest, fifteen minutes since the previous successful score, and a 17-17 tie still on the board, Nebraska opted to forgo the easy field goal and instead attempted to go for it on 4th and inches to create a larger lead margin, but the attempt failed, and both teams were forced to settle for a tie. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#17 Colorado at #13 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #17 {{cfb link|year=1973|school=University of Colorado at Boulder|team=Colorado Buffaloes|title=Colorado}} | Host = '''#13 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 3| V3 = 6| V4 = 7 | H1 = 14| H2 = 14| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1973-11-03 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,555 }} {{AFB game box end}} Colorado never really had a chance in this game, as Nebraska rolled out to an early 28-3 lead by the half. The final Cornhusker touchdown was a change of plans, after a field goal setup was moved towards the end zone due to a Colorado penalty, and Nebraska instead decided to run one in. The 4th quarter Buffalo touchdown was made on a trick play against Nebraska reserves who had entered the game to mop up. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Iowa State at #11 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1973|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | Host = '''#11 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 10| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1973-11-10 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,503 }} {{AFB game box end}} Once again, Nebraska ran out to a substantial early lead and coasted in for the win, as the game was essentially decided when the Cornhuskers put in a 67 yard pass touchdown just before the half. Nebraska reserves entered the game in the 4th and put in a touchdown to further pad the win. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#10 Nebraska at Kansas State''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#10 Nebraska''' | Host = [[1973 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]] | V1 = 10| V2 = 13| V3 = 7| V4 = 20 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1973-11-17 | Location = [[Bill Snyder Family Football Stadium|KSU Stadium]], [[Manhattan, Kansas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 42,000 }} {{AFB game box end}} Kansas State never was in this game, as the Cornhuskers blasted the Wildcats for a 23-0 1st half lead and never really slowed down, rolling up 612 yards of total offense along the way. The performances of Nebraska IB [[Tony Davis (American football)|Tony Davis]] and IB John O'Leary on the day marked the first time two Cornhusker runners exceeded 100 yards in the same game. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#10 Nebraska at #3 Oklahoma''' [box score] | Visitor = #10 Nebraska | Host = '''#3 [[1973 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]]''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 14| H2 = 0| H3 = 6| H4 = 7 | Date = 1973-11-23 | Location = [[Gaylord Family Oklahoma Memorial Stadium|Oklahoma Memorial Stadium]], [[Norman, Oklahoma]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 61,826 }} {{AFB game box end}} Oklahoma completely dismantled Nebraska in every way, as the Cornhuskers were shut out for the first time since [[1968 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|1968]], an indignity that would not be repeated until [[1991 Miami Hurricanes football team|Miami]] defeated [[1991 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] in the {{Alternate links|1992 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl|title=1992 Orange Bowl}} eighteen years later. The Cornhuskers were held to just 74 ground yards and 174 yards of total offense as the Nebraska offense never crossed mid-field. {{-}} ===Texas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#8 Texas vs #12 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = #8 {{cfb link|year=1973|school=The University of Texas at Austin|team=Texas Longhorns|title=Texas}} | Host = '''#12 Nebraska''' | V1 = 3| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 3| H3 = 13| H4 = 3 | Date = 1974-01-01 | Location = [[Cotton Bowl (stadium)|Cotton Bowl]],
[[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], [[Texas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,500 }} {{AFB game box end}} [[Southwest Conference|SWC]] champion [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]] put up the first points early in the 1st quarter with a field goal, but never saw the scoreboard again as Nebraska fought back to a 3-3 tie by the half, and then shut down the Longhorns' efforts afterwards by blocking a field goal and recovering a Texas fumble along the way to creating a comfortable lead by the end of the 3rd quarter. It was the Huskers fifth consecutive bowl victory. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{See also|1973 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- ! Poll !! Pre !! Wk 1 !! Wk 2 !! Wk 3 !! Wk 4 !! Wk 5 !! Wk 6 !! Wk 7 !! Wk 8 !! Wk 9 !! Wk 10 !! Wk 11 !! Wk 12 !! Wk 13 !! Final |- style="text-align:center;" ! [[David Humm|Dave Humm]], Bob Thornton |} ==1973 Team Players in the NFL== The 1973 Nebraska Cornhuskers seniors selected in the [[1974 NFL Draft]]:[http://www.pro-football-reference.com/draft/1974.htm Pro Football Reference.com] -
